displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s when you’ll be due. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: And look, look I need three still. I need that one, and I needed the one for, from that scooter, and I need Doctor: But, I told you I’m not giving you for the scooter. Patient: I mean, not scooter, I mean the walker. Doctor: For the walker with the seat. Yeah. Okay. Patient: Look, Dr bring in uh, uh, a script, showing that, ‘cuz I lost that when I lost all my ID, sayin’ that I got Doctor: So, you lost the script? Patient: No. The paper that said that I have, no, that you wrote me and said that I have prostate cancer, all Doctor: Okay. You lost that, too? Patient: I’ve been lost that. I’ve been lost that.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Disabled: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Disabled

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …and we’re gonna go over just the research part of it, so this is literally bio-specimen acquiring study which means when after we biopsy we’re gonna take several passes more to get extra stuff and that’s the end. And we won’t do it – Patient: Take the whole - Doctor: Take the whole thing out! (laughs) Patient: No, take the whole damn thing out. Patient: Take it all! Doctor: I know. The needle is yeh big and this thing is still yeh big so uh we would have to do a lot of passes. Patient: da Vinci procedure, da Vinci procedure. Doctor: Look at you. Get you on the table just like that. (laughs) Patient: da Vinci procedure (makes whistle noise) Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Snip, snip, snip, bzzz. (makes various noises) Doctor: See that. You’re

Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: Or if you want to eat iron-rich foods, uh, like- Family Member: But you’re thinking this is basically because of the medication? The study medication? Doctor: Yeah. I’m pretty sure. I’m pretty sure because, I mean, he actually had some degree of mild anemia before he went on the study. Part of that could have been from the cancer of the bone or marrow, specifically, but clearly when he went on the drug, it got worse, and it dropped back one to two points. So, uh, but you might need a transfusion, however. But that’s a possibility. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: So as of today, you know, stopping the . Okay? Uh, let’s plan to do, uh, forgot what the lab was. Is it K___? Family Member: It’s K___ lab. L___ will, uh, communicate with A___ from K___, and she’ll, uh, we’ll send her the script. Doctor: Please let L___ know about this. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we’ll get you a prescription through K___ to do a blood test next Tuesday, let’s say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or whatever day works for you. And, and that’s one of the precautions to see if, if the stopping of the drug for a week is causing the hemoglobin to increase on its own. And if it’s not, and we need some help with that, that’s when a blood transfusion would come into play.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m not exactly sure when that will happen. But it accelerates and that happens sooner. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: If it continues at the same pace you know if it increases by one or two decimal points, who knows, it may take you know six to nine months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Maybe up to twelve months. So one of the things that I wanted to discuss with both of you today is what we would do if it reached one. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay so the first thing would be to check and see uh if the cancer is still visible or invisible. In other words can we see the cancer on scan – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - whether bone scan or CAT scan? Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Or is it still invisible and can we not see it? Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s not bad. There’s nothing wrong with ya. You know, if you’re achy- Patient: Just tired. Doctor: Just ‘cuz, you know, you’re just take a couple of Advil, and you just say, “I, I gotta go take a nap.” Most people don’t notice much. Uh, just like, “Okay, they told me I’d feel it this weekend.” Uh. Family Member: Okay! Doctor: Most people really just lose the end of their day. You know, they’re at work, work, work, and they just sorta say, “Oh.” And they’re toast. Patient: And when the end of the day is all over, you nap. Doctor: Mm, hmm. But it sounds like you’re pretty good about sorta if I have to take a nap today, I will or if I - Patient: Oh yeah, if I know I gotta work late, I nap now and stay up late later, and sleep when I can ‘cuz I’m having some days with no troubles. It’s Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: Okay, so those orders are out. So, you’re going to the purple wall. Swipe your card. And they will sorta set up the follow-up visits, and then they can take you upstairs. You’ll go onto the second floor and swipe your card again, and that will tell them that you’re here for your flu shot. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay.

Patient: From Dubai to South Africa was nine hours. Doctor: How far to Dubai? It’s like twelve hours? Patient: Oh, man, it was about fourteen, sixteen hours. Doctor: Man, you guys are- Doctor: You had to travel. Doctor: Yeah. They do like the circle route, I guess. Patient: Yeah. I don’t understand it. Doctor: I think it’s, it’s, well, because the earth’s a circle, globe. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: If you fly straight it’s longer. Patient: Right. Oh. Doctor: Because I don’t quite understand it. Patient: I didn’t know that.

Patient: Right. Doctor: so at this moment. One, stop Xtandi; two, we’re going to give you some Xofigo paperwork and you’re going to do some of the – just give him some of the - Healthcare Professional: Lupron. Doctor: Lupron. And then we’ll send you on to see Dr. ___ for a consult. All of that is not a huge rush, but we’re just gonna move it along. Family Member: Yeah, because we’re leaving February fifth, so. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: So. Patient: So you don’t want me to take Xtandi at all anymore? Healthcare Professional: No, stop it. Family Member: Can we donate it to somebody that needs it? Healthcare Professional: Yeah, bring it back in. Doctor: Bring it back to us and we’ll make sure it gets recycled to the next person, absolutely. Family Member: To the next person who needs it.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And my recommendation to do that would be a little bit stronger if the cancer is visible – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - on the scan, especially if it has progressed. And the recommendation would be weaker; in other words, I would be open to delaying the hormone therapy a bit longer if the cancer cannot be seen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In other words if it’s just the PSA rising and the absence of any visible cancer on the scan. Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one? Doctor: When it goes above one. Patient: And that would be here at JH? Doctor: I would recommend that; it’s not absolutely necessary. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Typically you can do everything in one single day. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know with you, you know what I worry about is sometimes you know, we write prostate cancer on the order form so the doctor over says, “Oh, yeah, there it is, there it is.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they may be right, or they may be calling what we normally if you had a scan and they’d say, “ that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis”. Patient: Right. Doctor: Prostate Cancer likes to go to the lymph nodes, and so they're oft- they have to start small. And so we all have lymph nodes, but in this case, they say yeah, there’s lymph nodes- Patient: Right. Doctor: -there's a lot of them, so that could be cancer. Patient: Right. DOC. They didn't say it was cancer. It could be cancer. Doctor: The stuff in your back Two different modes of how we look at your back are telling us different things about different places. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So the tiebreaker really would be to get another test.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, a good question. It’s something that I have to always make sure people understand. At this stage in the game you should never be on a placebo only trial. Like it can never be either drug X or you’re crap out of luck. No, that’s never gonna happen. Okay? Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And if anybody ever offers you that, that’s bad news. That’s just ethically wrong. So, we have a lot of watchdogs, safeguards, everybody’s looking to make sure that we don’t do something like that. Patient: Okay, Alright. Doctor: Yeah, keep going. Patient: I’ll get these tests done and then we’ll come back to see you. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Patient: And then the rest is done here? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: The treatment is here? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: it took them months and months. Doctor: Months. Uh we will factor that in. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So that you know you can have your trip, yeah. Patient: Say okay, we’re all set to start, but oh by the way Doctor: Right. Patient: I need two weeks off. Doctor: Yeah. No, no, no, we’ll figure it out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just keep things moving and we’ll figure it out. Patient: So J___ told me that his promise to you is he said he’ll get me squared away medically and then - Doctor: Yes, and then it’s time for us to take over! (chuckles) Patient: Yeah. ___ called me last night. He said we’re taking a break in oncology and we’re going to do some medicine. And I said okay.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Uhm and you’re in remission unless it recurs, comes back. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Last question, or uh maybe not. Mistletoe. I’ve had some friends that have said maybe that can help with side effects, things of that nature. If I were to research that, would that in any way – Doctor: Yeah, well thanks for asking that, so mistletoe is contraindicated certainly during chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it interferes with chem. I would say also during radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The reason is so you know everybody wants to be helpful and you know give you all kinds of natural products and things like mistletoe or kabuki mushrooms or whatever. The problem is that a lot of them are antioxidants. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So they’re really good stuff, except when you’re trying to kill bad things, and then they interfere because one of the things we’re trying to do in chemo is make reactive oxygen species which kill, make the DNA not work and breaks up and then the cells break up. If you give a medicine like mistletoe to interfere with the creation of those uh you know, what’s basically hydrogen peroxide that kills ah the cells, then you’re interfering with chemotherapy and radiation therapies. Family Member: The effectiveness of the chemo Patient: So that would be something . Uh nutrition – Then I’m scheduled to speak with someone from a company out of Colorado called

Patient: For how long? Doctor: Well that’s what the consent will give you the exact details Patient: Okay, Yeah. Doctor: of how many times a week, but the first few weeks typically are very, what this is called is a Phase I study. So it’s an earlier setting like I said the combination really we don’t have a good handle on what to expect in terms of toxicities, what dose, etc. So one of the side effects that has been noted so far is that the platelets can drop with this medication. So that is something of course the blood counts will be monitored anyway. Besides that kidney function, liver function, all that will also be monitored and checked. You go – undergo EKG monitoring that will be hard test like and echo before you start. So there is a lot of components. One additional component is that you probably will need to do a biopsy again as part of the study. Doctor: So that’s something to think about before you say yes or no. Patient: And does platelets dropping how would that affect me physically? Doctor: Well if it gets really low then it can cause bleeding and things like that - Family Member: Like internal? Doctor: -but the whole idea of this closed monitoring is to not let it get that far. But you know obviously if you notice any bleeding, nose bleeds, gum bleeds, blood in the urine, whatever I need to know right away. Family Member: But how about the bleeding that’s rectal bleeding that he’s having now. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so has you know we’ll probably have to wait and see, but changes are that should respond to just medical management and will clear up. Family Member: Yeah and you know we had the colonoscopy and the… Doctor: Yeah

Family Member: Right. Doctor: But I also would prefer the two of you be the voice, you know. ‘Cuz for me to go over it four different times just because -- Family Member: Right. Doctor: Someone’s not able to get here makes it difficult. Family Member: Right. Patient: Well she has court today. Her ex-husband is – Family Member: Being a pain in the ass. Patient: He wants more custody of the kids. So, she has her own mess. Doctor: I get it. Well, what we would be doing is we’d be seeing a lot of you. So, again, some of those visits she – you know, hopefully, the court stuff is better that she can come down with you. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Um. So, does that make sense to try that and go that route? I mean, or is it really you want to think about it more – uh, step back and again talk to your doctor about the chemo again? Do you want to get his opinion or her opinion about the trial? Um. Patient: I think the, the trial’s a little more targeted. The chemo is more general.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And, then, you could move into that study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are AR-V7 negative and, uh, phase one study is of more interest to you, we can say, “Okay, you’re gonna stop as of this date the, the current study.” Patient: Right-- the drugs Doctor: And then we could reserve the slot for the new trial. Patient: Okay. Okay. That works. Doctor: Questions? Family Member: I do, I think that, uh, one of the, I guess, questions that came up in my mind was the signs of the cancer development in the adrenal is it consistent that it would be prostate cancer or we just don’t even know Doctor: Yeah. I mean, the assumption is that it is prostate cancer. Why give him a second cancer? Uh. So, that’s the assumption. You know, the adrenal gland can have benign tumors in it. Okay? Um. You know, if prostate cancer went in there, that would be a possible reason why it would bleed. Um. Sometimes the adrenal gland just doesn’t get a good blood supply, and it does bleed. Or, if you’re under stress, or like today with your blood pressure shooting through the roof, but your scans were yesterday. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh. It’s pretty nonspecific. Your aspirin puts you at a higher risk for like various
